Present Illness:The patient reports upper abdominal pain accompanied by radiating back pain, with pain severity gradually increasing. Pain score is 4 out of 10, with no impact on sleep. Symptoms worsen after eating, but oral acetaminophen provides relief. Since the onset of symptoms, the patient has not experienced bloating, weight loss, or changes in appetite.
Physical Condition:None

history.doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
history.standard_patient: I've been having abdominal pain for three months now.
history.patient: "I've been experiencing persistent abdominal discomfort for the past quarter, and being well-versed in the art of deadlines, I must say this ongoing issue has me quite concerned."

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that with me. Can you please describe the nature of the abdominal discomfort?
history.memory: [Relevant Information]: The patient reports upper abdominal pain accompanied by radiating back pain, with pain severity gradually increasing. Pain score is 4 out of 10, with no impact on sleep. Symptoms worsen after eating, but oral acetaminophen provides relief.
history.standard_patient: The pain is located in my upper abdomen and it radiates to my back. It's not constant, but it has been gradually getting worse over time. On a pain scale from 1 to 10, I would rate it as a 4. Surprisingly, it doesn't really disturb my sleep. However, I notice the symptoms intensify after I eat something. Taking oral acetaminophen seems to provide some relief though.
history.patient: As a corporate cog, I've noticed this nagging discomfort in my upper abdominal region, which occasionally shoots through to my back. It's not a 24/7 ordeal, but it's been on a slow yet steady incline on the agony meter. On that note, I'd peg it around a 4 out of 10 on the pain spectrum. Oddly enough, it doesn't mess with my REM cycle. However, post-meal, the situation seems to escalate. Popping a couple of acetaminophen does take the edge off, though.

history.doctor: Thank you for providing that information. Can you please tell me about your age and gender?
history.standard_patient: I'm 38 years old and female.
history.patient: I'm a 38-year-old female, holding a seasoned corporate stance with a background steeped in higher education, and I'm well-versed in the lexicon of our professional realm, all while maintaining a knack for casual conversation.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Can you please tell me about any possible causes of your symptoms, such as travel history or past medical history?
history.standard_patient: I have a past medical history of asthma, which is poorly controlled. I use inhaled salbutamol and corticosteroids regularly. No recent travels. In terms of family history, there's celiac disease and colon cancer.
history.patient: As a corporate cubicle dweller with an educated tongue, I've got a long-standing asthma issue that's not exactly under wraps, mate. I'm reliant on my trusty salbutamol inhaler and a course of corticosteroids to keep me going. No jet-setting adventures lately, though. On the family health front, there's a bit of a遗传 glitch with celiac disease and a history of the big C in the colon department.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Can you please tell me about any medical examinations you have undergone recently, such as X-rays or blood pressure tests?
history.standard_patient: I haven't undergone any recent medical examinations specific to my current issue. My last check-up was routine and didn't involve any X-rays or detailed blood work related to this pain.
history.patient: As a corporate cog, I haven't had any recent med checks tailored to my current predicament. My last physical was just a run-of-the-mill affair, devoid of any radiological inspections or comprehensive hematological analyses pertinent to this nagging ache.

Text.Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain lasting one day.
Text.Present Illness: The patient experienced sudden severe pain in the upper abdomen one day ago without any apparent cause. The pain was constant, without episodic worsening or radiation to other areas. Symptoms included nausea and vomiting six times, with the vomitus consisting of gastric contents totaling about 1000 milliliters, containing no blood or worms.
Text.Past Medical History: Has a history of 'gastric ulcers' for three years, intermittently treated with oral medications. Denies history of 'hypertension, diabetes,' etc. No known drug or food allergies, no history of trauma or major surgery, and unclear history of vaccinations.
Text.Examinations:
Complete blood count shows: white blood cells at 2.46*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 79.0%, lymphocyte percentage at 14.0%, neutrophils count at 1.95*10^9/L, lymphocytes count at 0.34*10^9/L, hemoglobin at 159.00 g/L. 

 Biochemical report indicates: total protein at 45.7 g/L, albumin at 22.9 g/L, globulin at 23.60 g/L. 

 Upper abdominal CT: <\image00002.jpg>.
Text.Diagnosis: 1. Upper gastrointestinal perforation, 2. Cholecystolithiasis, cholecystitis, liver cyst, 3. Thickened ascending colon, 4. Acute diffuse peritonitis
Text.Treatment: Surgical repair of gastric pyloric perforation

Image.00002.jpg: Free air and fluid in the abdominal cavity, blurred fat stranding in the intestinal lumen, suggesting hollow visceral perforation. 2. Liver cyst 3. Gallstones, cholecystitis 4. Thickened ascending colon, further examination recommended

Patient Information:Male, 66 years old, farmer
Chief Complaint:Sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain lasting one day.
Present Illness:The patient experienced sudden severe pain in the upper abdomen one day ago without any apparent cause. The pain was constant, without episodic worsening or radiation to other areas. Symptoms included nausea and vomiting six times, with the vomitus consisting of gastric contents totaling about 1000 milliliters, containing no blood or worms.
Physical Condition:None
Past Medical History:Has a history of 'gastric ulcers' for three years, intermittently treated with oral medications. Denies history of 'hypertension, diabetes,' etc. No known drug or food allergies, no history of trauma or major surgery, and unclear history of vaccinations.

history.patient: I've been havin' this real bad pain in my belly up high, started all of a sudden yesterday mornin', and it ain't let up since.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Can you please tell me your age and gender?
history.standard_patient: I'm a 66-year-old male.
history.patient: I'm a 66-year-old fella, working the land since I could walk.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Have you had any recent travel or been to any places that might have exposed you to any infections or diseases?

history.standard_patient: I have a history of gastric ulcers for three years, which has been intermittently treated with oral medications. I deny having hypertension, diabetes, or any other major chronic conditions.
history.patient: I've been dealing with belly ulcers off and on for three years now, fixing it with them pills the doc prescribed. Ain't got no high blood pressure, sugar problems, or any other long-term issues that bug folks usually.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Have you had any recent changes in your diet or lifestyle that might be related to your current symptoms?
history.standard_patient: No, there haven't been any significant changes in my diet or lifestyle recently that I think could be causing this.
history.patient: Nah, ain't made no big changes in what I eat or how I live lately that I figure could be bringin' this on.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Have you had any recent physical examinations or tests done that might be related to your current symptoms?
history.standard_patient: No, I haven't had any recent physicals or tests done. This pain came on suddenly and unexpectedly.
history.patient: Well, doc, I ain't seen a doctor or had any of them fancy checks lately. This ache just popped up outta nowhere, real sudden-like.

Text.Chief Complaint: Upper abdominal distension and pain for 7 hours
Text.Present Illness: The patient consumed a high-fat diet last night and began experiencing pain in the upper abdomen around 9 AM today, primarily in the upper left quadrant. The abdominal pain is continuous, severe, and intolerable, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. There was no significant relief of abdominal pain after vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: None.
Text.Examinations:
White blood cell count is 15.14 x 10^9/L, electrolytes are largely normal, triglycerides are 9.44 mmol/L, liver and kidney functions are normal, calcitonin is normal, and blood glucose is normal.  

  Upper abdominal CT shows: <\image00003.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes omeprazole for acid suppression, low molecular weight heparin for lipid reduction, somatostatin to inhibit pancreatic enzyme secretion, fluid replacement to maintain electrolyte balance, and moxifloxacin for anti-infection.

Image.00003.jpg: Consistent with pancreatitis with peripancreatic effusion, and fatty liver.

Text.Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain and diarrhea for 3 days
Text.Present Illness: The patient's abdominal pain started around the umbilical region and moved to the lower right abdomen, worsening gradually. The pain is sharp and exacerbated by movement and eating. Oral painkillers like acetaminophen provide partial relief. The pain is associated with low-grade fever and decreased appetite. The patient reports watery stools five times per day, with no mucus or blood. Diarrhea started after taking antibiotics for a recent upper respiratory infection.
Text.Past Medical History: History of diabetes, well-controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. No history of surgeries. Smoker for 15 years. No family history of hereditary gastrointestinal diseases.

Text.Chief Complaint: Two months post-acute pancreatitis recovery, experiencing abdominal bloating and decreased appetite for half a month.
Text.Present Illness: The patient developed persistent dull pain in the upper abdomen, particularly in the upper left quadrant, two months ago following overeating. Accompanied by nausea, vomiting of gastric contents, and developed generalized skin jaundice and dark urine. No chills, high fever, cough, phlegm, or breathing difficulties. Diagnosed at our hospital with acute pancreatitis and steatohepatitis.
Text.Past Medical History: History of acute pancreatitis two months ago treated with medication. Denies history of surgeries, trauma, drug allergies, and denies contact with infectious diseases such as tuberculosis.
Text.Examinations:
Laboratory findings show: ALT: 65.2 U/L, AST: 32.0 U/L, GGT: 126.0 U/L, TBIL: 22.5 umol/L, DBIL: 10.3 umol/L, IBIL: 12.2 umol/L, serum amylase 217 U/L.  

 CT shows: <\image00007.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Administered famotidine 20 mg in 100 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride solution, twice daily intravenous drip to inhibit gastric acid secretion, mesna for symptomatic treatment.

Image.00007.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, no abnormal density in the parenchyma, no dilation in intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, normal size of the gallbladder, no clear positive stones. Pancreas is full, streak shadows around the pancreas, a round-like low-density shadow in front of the pancreas head, approximately 3.3*2.6 cm. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal area.

Accompanied by nausea, vomiting of gastric contents, and developed generalized skin jaundice and dark urine. No chills, high fever, cough, phlegm, or breathing difficulties. Diagnosed at our hospital with acute pancreatitis and steatohepatitis.
Physical Condition:None

history.standard_patient: Hello, I've been experiencing abdominal bloating and a decreased appetite for about half a month now. This is two months after recovering from acute pancreatitis.
history.patient: Hey doc, so like, I've had this weird belly swelling and haven't really been hungry for about two weeks now. This is all happening after I got better from that bad pancreas thing, you know, acute pancreatitis, like a couple months back. And yeah, it's been a bit tough keeping up with my studies and all at school.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information with me. Can you please tell me your age and gender?
history.standard_patient: I'm an 18-year-old male.

history.standard_patient: No, I haven't traveled recently, and I haven't been in contact with anyone who's been sick.
history.patient: Yeah, so, like, I haven't gone on any trips lately or, you know, hung out with anyone who's been, uh, sick at school or anything.

history.memory: [Relevant Information]: The patient developed persistent dull pain in the upper abdomen, particularly in the upper left quadrant, two months ago following overeating. Accompanied by nausea, vomiting of gastric contents, and developed generalized skin jaundice and dark urine.

I also experience nausea and have been vomiting gastric contents. Additionally, I've noticed generalized skin jaundice and my urine has turned dark.
history.patient: So, like, I've got this nagging ache in my upper belly, mostly on the left side, man. It kicked in after this huge feast I had, maybe two months back. I'm also kinda queasy and sometimes I just gotta hurl, you know, like my stomach's saying 'no more studying fuel'. And, weirdly, my skin's looking a bit yellowish all over, plus my pee's turned this dark color. It's messing with my study game.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information with me. Based on your symptoms and medical history, it is possible that you may have developed a complication related to your previous acute pancreatitis. The yellowing of your skin and dark-colored urine could be indicative of jaundice, which is a sign of liver dysfunction. The abdominal pain and swelling could be due to inflammation or infection in the pancreas or surrounding organs. I would recommend further testing, such as a CT scan of the abdomen and blood tests to evaluate your liver function and pancreatic enzymes. In the meantime, it is important to rest and avoid any strenuous activities that may exacerbate your symptoms.

history.doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
history.standard_patient: I've been experiencing pain and limited movement in my right thumb for a year now.
history.patient: I've been havin' this naggin' pain and can't bend my right thumb proper for about a year now.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Can you please tell me more about the pain?
history.standard_patient: The pain started suddenly about a year ago without any apparent cause. It's mostly a dull ache, but it can intensify when I try to use my thumb, like when gripping or pinching something. It's also become more stiff, making it difficult to move freely.
history.patient: So, doc, about a year back, out of the blue, this nagging pain just popped up. It's mostly a low-grade throb, but if I try to grab or squeeze something with my thumb, it sure does kick up a notch. And it's gotten all stiff-like, making it hard to move it around proper.

history.doctor: Thank you for providing more details about the pain. Can you please tell me about any other symptoms you may be experiencing, such as swelling or numbness in the thumb or hand?
history.standard_patient: No, I haven't noticed any swelling or numbness. Just the pain and limited movement in my thumb.
history.patient: Nah, ain't seen no puffiness or that pins and needles feeling. Just this here pain and my thumb don't bend like it used to.

history.standard_patient: No, I haven't had any recent injuries or accidents to my thumb or hand.
history.patient: Nah, ain't had no bumps or tumbles lately that hurt my thumb or hand.

history.standard_patient: Yes, I have definitely noticed a decrease in my grip strength. It's harder for me to hold onto things firmly, and tasks that require fine motor skills, like typing or even buttoning my shirt, have become quite challenging.
history.patient: Yeah, I've surely felt like my hands ain't as strong as they used to be. Gripping stuff is getting tricky, and doing fiddly work, like fixing fences or even tying my boots, has turned into a real struggle.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Based on your symptoms and the information you have provided, it is possible that you may be suffering from a condition called De Quervain's tenosynovitis. This is a condition that affects the tendons around the base of the thumb, causing pain and stiffness. It is often caused by repetitive motions, such as typing or using a smartphone. To confirm this diagnosis, I would need to examine your hand and perform a few tests. Have you had any X-rays or other imaging tests done recently?

history.doctor: Thank you for providing the X-ray. I can see that there is a small fracture in the base of the thumb, which is likely the cause of your pain and difficulty moving your thumb. This type of injury is often referred to as a "gamekeeper's thumb" or "skier's thumb" and is caused by a forceful impact or bending of the thumb. The fracture appears to be stable, which means that it is not displaced and should heal on its own with proper rest and immobilization. I will recommend that you wear a splint or cast to keep your thumb immobile for a period of time to allow the bone to heal. Additionally, I will prescribe some pain medication to help manage the discomfort. It is important that you follow the instructions for the splint or cast and avoid any activities that could cause further injury to your thumb. If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to ask.

diagnosis_self:
Patient Information:

* Name: John Doe
* Age: 45
* Gender: Male
* Occupation: Office worker

Present Illness:

* John Doe presents with a history of gallstones and chronic cholecystitis, which he was diagnosed with during a routine medical check-up approximately half a decade ago.
* In the past semester, he has been experiencing on-and-off acid reflux-like symptoms in the upper left quadrant of his abdomen, without any obvious trigger.

Past Medical History:

* Gallstones and chronic cholecystitis diagnosed during routine medical check-up approximately half a decade ago.

Examination Items and Results:

* Physical examination revealed no abnormalities.
* Abdominal ultrasound showed multiple gallstones in the gallbladder, with no evidence of obstruction or inflammation.

Diagnosis:

* Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, it is likely that the gallstones are causing inflammation in the gallbladder, leading to chronic cholecystitis. The patient's symptoms are consistent with biliary colic, which is a type of pain that occurs when the gallstones block the bile duct.

Treatment Plan:

* The patient will be referred to a surgeon for further evaluation and possible surgical intervention, such as laparoscopic cholecystectomy, to remove the gallbladder and gallstones.
* The patient will be advised to avoid fatty or greasy foods, as these can trigger biliary colic.
* The patient will be prescribed pain medication to manage any discomfort associated with the gallstones and chronic cholecystitis.

Text.Chief Complaint: Persistent upper abdominal pain for one day
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports continuous severe pain in the upper abdomen that started one day ago without any apparent cause, radiating to the back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting three times, totaling approximately 800 milliliters of gastric content, without blood or worms. The pain did not alleviate after vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: History of Type 2 diabetes for 2 years, well-controlled with long-term oral medication.
Text.Examinations:
Palpation: Reduced abdominal breathing, slightly distended abdomen, no visible intestinal peristalsis or bowel waves, liver and spleen not palpable beyond the costal margin, generalized abdominal tenderness without rebound pain or muscle guarding, most severe in the upper left quadrant, no costovertebral angle tenderness.  

 Abdominal CT: <\image00016.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: white blood cells at 10.19*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 83.30%, lymphocyte percentage at 10.40%, neutrophil count at 8.49*10^9/L. Urinalysis: ketones +3, glucose +4, protein +3. Bicarbonate 12.81 mmol/L, blood sugar 14.44 mmol/L.
Text.Treatment: Exploratory laparotomy, splenectomy

Image.00016.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, decreased liver parenchymal density, no dilation in intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts, normal-sized gallbladder with no obvious stones. Normal spleen morphology, size, and density, slightly full pancreas, flaky dense shadows around the pancreas, thickened anterior renal fascia of the left kidney. An oval low-density shadow is visible within the right kidney substance, protruding from the renal contour. Suggests acute pancreatitis with peripancreatic effusion, fatty liver, right renal cyst.

Text.Chief Complaint: Seizures and fall after stopping medication for meningioma and epilepsy diagnosed a year ago, with pain and bleeding from the right eyebrow arch for one hour.
Text.Present Illness: Diagnosed a year ago at a tertiary hospital in Beijing with 'epilepsy caused by meningioma', not surgically treated, and on long-term treatment with sodium valproate extended-release tablets, 1 tablet twice daily. Missed medication yesterday, experienced sudden limb convulsions, loss of consciousness, and frothing at the mouth an hour ago, which resolved after 3 minutes. This was followed by a fall causing pain and minor bleeding from the right eyebrow arch, which stopped on its own.
Text.Past Medical History: History of 'meningioma and epilepsy' for one year, 'hepatitis B and cirrhosis' for 20 years, treated with long-term medication.

Text.Treatment: Intravenous injection for relief

文本:
Patient Information:Female, 73 years old, farmer
Chief Complaint:Seizures and fall after stopping medication for meningioma and epilepsy diagnosed a year ago, with pain and bleeding from the right eyebrow arch for one hour.
Present Illness:Diagnosed a year ago at a tertiary hospital in Beijing with 'epilepsy caused by meningioma', not surgically treated, and on long-term treatment with sodium valproate extended-release tablets, 1 tablet twice daily. Missed medication yesterday, experienced sudden limb convulsions, loss of consciousness, and frothing at the mouth an hour ago, which resolved after 3 minutes. This was followed by a fall causing pain and minor bleeding from the right eyebrow arch, which stopped on its own.
Physical Condition:None
Past Medical History:History of 'meningioma and epilepsy' for one year, 'hepatitis B and cirrhosis' for 20 years, treated with long-term medication.

history.doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
history.standard_patient: I've been having seizures and fell after stopping my medication for meningioma and epilepsy, which was diagnosed a year ago. Additionally, I've had pain and bleeding from my right eyebrow arch for an hour.
history.patient: I've been havin' these fits and took a tumble since I stopped takin' them pills for that brain lump and them shakin' spells the doc found last year. On top of that, there's been pain and bleedin' from above my right eye, near the brow, goin' on for about an hour now.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information with me. Can you please tell me your age and gender?
history.standard_patient: I am a 73-year-old female.
history.patient: I'm a 73-year-old lady, been workin' the land all my life.

history.doctor: Thank you for that information. Can you please tell me if you have any history of travel to areas with malaria or other tropical diseases?
history.standard_patient: No, I haven't traveled to any such areas recently.
history.patient: Nah, I ain't been to no places like that lately.

history.doctor: Thank you for that information. Can you please tell me if you have any past medical history, such as any previous illnesses or surgeries?
history.memory: [Relevant Information]: Past Medical History:History of 'meningioma and epilepsy' for one year, 'hepatitis B and cirrhosis' for 20 years, treated with long-term medication.
history.standard_patient: I have a history of meningioma and epilepsy for one year, and hepatitis B and cirrhosis for 20 years, which are being managed with long-term medication.
history.patient: I've been dealing with a brain lump and seizures for a year now, and got the liver sickness and scarring for two decades. Doc's got me on some long-lasting pills to keep 'em in check.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information with me. Can you please tell me if you have any family history of similar conditions or illnesses?
history.standard_patient: No, there isn't any known family history of similar conditions.
history.patient: Nah, ain't nobody in my kin that I know of who's had something like this before.

history.doctor: Thank you for that information. Can you please tell me if you have any allergies to medications or if you are currently taking any other medications besides the ones prescribed for your brain lump and seizures?
history.memory: [Relevant Information]: Patient has a history of 'hepatitis B and cirrhosis' for 20 years, treated with long-term medication. No specific medications are mentioned except for sodium valproate extended-release tablets for epilepsy caused by meningioma. Allergy information is not provided.
history.standard_patient: I am not aware of any allergies to medications. Currently, I am only taking sodium valproate extended-release tablets for my epilepsy.
history.patient: I don't know if I'm allergic to any medicines. Right now, I'm just takin' them long-actin' seizure pills, sodium valproate they call it, for my fits.

history.doctor: Thank you for that information. Based on what you have told me, it is possible that you may be experiencing a side effect of the medication you are taking for your seizures. The pain and bleeding near your right eye could be a result of increased blood pressure or a side effect of the medication. I would recommend that you stop taking the medication immediately and seek medical attention as soon as possible. In the meantime, you can try to lower your blood pressure by staying hydrated, avoiding salty foods, and getting plenty of rest.

Text.Chief Complaint: Chronic constipation for 20 years, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distension, and cessation of gas and bowel movements for 3 days.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports chronic constipation starting 20 years ago without an apparent cause, with hard stools occurring every 3 to 5 days and difficulty defecating, but without pain unless attempting to defecate, and no bloody or purulent stools. Previously diagnosed locally as 'constipation' and improved with oral laxatives (name and dosage unknown); intermittently medicated over 20 years. Constipation recurred 3 days ago, accompanied by episodic severe pain in the right upper abdomen, no radiation, and accompanied by nausea and vomiting five times of gastric contents, totaling about 1000 milliliters, without blood or worms. Abdominal pain slightly reduced after vomiting, accompanied by abdominal distension and cessation of gas and stool passage.
Text.Past Medical History: 20-year history of constipation.
Text.Examinations:
Upright abdominal plain film: <\image00018.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: white blood cells 9.34*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage 88.60%, lymphocyte percentage 7.50%, neutrophils 8.27*10^9/L, lymphocytes 0.70*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Upon hospital admission, comprehensive tests were performed including continuous gastrointestinal decompression, warm soapy water enema of 800 ml, maintaining fluid and electrolyte and acid-base balance. The patient's underlying condition includes deficiency of yin and body fluids, dry and hard stools, lack of facial radiance, pale lips, and a fine and rough pulse. In traditional Chinese medicine, diagnosed as blood and yin deficiency, treatment should nourish yin and moisten dryness. Administered intestinal moistening pills and modified Shengjiang Chengqi Tang via gastric tube, 150 ml, tube clamped for 2 hours, resulting in substantial bowel movement the next day, symptoms and signs resolved.

Image.00018.jpg: No free gas under the diaphragm, intestinal gas and dilation in the right upper abdomen with a large gas-fluid level visible, no clear positive stone shadows in the path of both kidneys and ureters, both abdominal fat lines are still clear. Indicates right upper abdominal intestinal dilation and gas accumulation, large gas-fluid level visible, correlated clinically.

治疗: Upon hospital admission, comprehensive tests were performed including continuous gastrointestinal decompression, warm soapy water enema of 800 ml, maintaining fluid and electrolyte and acid-base balance. The patient's underlying condition includes deficiency of yin and body fluids, dry and hard stools, lack of facial radiance, pale lips, and a fine and rough pulse. Previously diagnosed locally as 'constipation' and improved with oral laxatives (name and dosage unknown); intermittently medicated over 20 years. Constipation recurred 3 days ago, accompanied by episodic severe pain in the right upper abdomen, no radiation, and accompanied by nausea and vomiting five times of gastric contents, totaling about 1000 milliliters, without blood or worms. history.doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
history.standard_patient: I've been experiencing chronic constipation for 20 years, and currently, I have abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distension. It's been 3 days since I had any gas or bowel movements.
history.patient: I've been struggling with being all backed up for 20 years straight, and lately, my belly's been achin', makin' me feel queasy and toss my cookies. My tummy's swollen like a ripe pumpkin, and it's been three whole days since I passed any wind or done my business.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing your symptoms with me. Can you please tell me your age and gender?

history.patient: Nah, ain't been nowhere special lately and my eatin' habits are just like always, steady as a tractor on its daily rounds.

history.doctor: Thank you for letting me know. Have you had any past medical history that could be related to your current symptoms?

history.standard_patient: Yes, I have a 20-year history of constipation, which has been a persistent issue for me. Other than that, my medical history is relatively unremarkable regarding this condition.
history.patient: Yeah, I've been struggling with constipation for 20 years now, it's been a real nagging problem. Other than that, I ain't had much trouble health-wise in that department.

However, I would like to confirm this diagnosis by reviewing the results of your recent medical examinations. Can you please tell me the results of your X-ray and blood pressure tests?

history.patient: Well, doc, I ain't had no fancy X-rays or them blood pressure checks lately. This here problem of mine started just a couple days back, so I figured I'd come straight to you for some fixin'.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the upper right abdomen one day after cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports that one month ago, she underwent a 'cholecystectomy and choledocholithotomy' due to 'gallbladder stones and common bile duct stones' at another hospital, with good postoperative recovery. One day ago, she experienced sudden severe continuous pain in the upper right abdomen without a clear cause, which was unbearable and radiated to the right shoulder and back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting of gastric contents without bile or coffee-ground material. The pain did not lessen after vomiting and was accompanied by fever with a body temperature of 37.8°C, no chills, and no jaundice.
Text.Past Medical History: History of gallbladder and common bile duct stones for 6 years, long-term intermittent medication use, underwent cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Flat abdomen, localized tenderness in the upper right abdomen and mid upper abdomen, no rebound tenderness or muscle tension, tympanic abdomen on percussion, bowel sounds 4-6 times per minute, no splashing or metallic sounds heard. 

  CT: <\image00019.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: WBC: 5.98*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage: 71.00%, lymphocyte percentage: 22.30%; neutrophil count: 3.97*10^9/L, lymphocyte count: 1.24*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Treatment with cefoperazone sodium and sulbactam sodium, and omeprazole injections to inhibit gastric acid secretion; intravenous phenobarbital for spasmolytic and analgesic treatment.

Image.00019.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, with punctate low-density areas in the parenchyma, no dilation of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Gallbladder not visible, strip-like low-density shadow in the gallbladder area, mild dilation of the common bile duct. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen and pancreas. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal areas, no fluid in the abdominal cavity.

 Complete blood count: WBC: 5.98*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage: 71.00%, lymphocyte percentage: 22.30%; neutrophil count: 3.97*10^9/L, lymphocyte count: 1.24*10^9/L.

文本:
Patient Information:Female, 51 years old, farmer
Chief Complaint:Pain in the upper right abdomen one day after cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Present Illness:The patient reports that one month ago, she underwent a 'cholecystectomy and choledocholithotomy' due to 'gallbladder stones and common bile duct stones' at another hospital, with good postoperative recovery. One day ago, she experienced sudden severe continuous pain in the upper right abdomen without a clear cause, which was unbearable and radiated to the right shoulder and back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting of gastric contents without bile or coffee-ground material. The pain did not lessen after vomiting and was accompanied by fever with a body temperature of 37.8°C, no chills, and no jaundice.
Physical Condition:None
Past Medical History:History of gallbladder and common bile duct stones for 6 years, long-term intermittent medication use, underwent cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.

history.doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
history.standard_patient: Hello, I'm experiencing pain in my upper right abdomen. This started one day ago, and I had a cholecystectomy with exploration of the common bile duct about a month back.
history.patient: Howdy doc, I've been havin' this real achin' pain up in my right side belly area. It kicked in yesterday, and it's been a month since I had that surgery to take out my gall bladder and they looked at that tube carryin' bile too.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Can you please tell me more about the pain?
history.standard_patient: The pain is quite severe and continuous, located in my upper right abdomen. It came on suddenly without any apparent reason. What's really concerning is that it extends to my right shoulder and back. I've also been feeling nauseous and have vomited stomach contents, but there was no bile or what looked like coffee grounds in it. Even after vomiting, the pain hasn't subsided. Additionally, I've had a low-grade fever, around 37.8°C, without any chills, and I haven't noticed any yellowing of my skin or eyes.
history.patient: Well, Doc, I got this real bad pain up in my right side, belly area, and it hit me outta nowhere. It's a persistent ache, and what's got me worried sick is it's shootin' all the way up to my right shoulder and back. I've been feelin' queasy, even tossed my cookies, but there wasn't no green stuff or anything that looked like coffee grinds in it. Odd thing is, even after that, the pain's stickin' around. I've got a bit of a fever, not too high, 'bout 37.8°C, no shivers though, and my skin ain't turned yellow nor my eyes neither.

history.doctor:
Thank you for providing more details about your symptoms. Based on your description, it is possible that you may be experiencing a complication from your recent surgery. I will need to ask you a few more questions to help me determine the most likely cause of your symptoms. 
Firstly, have you noticed any changes in your appetite or bowel movements since the surgery?
history.standard_patient: No, I haven't noticed any significant changes in my appetite or bowel movements.
history.patient: Nah, ain't noticed no big differences in how much I'm eatin' or how my insides are doin' their business.

history.doctor: Thank you for letting me know. Next, have you experienced any nausea or vomiting since the surgery?
history.memory: [Relevant Information]: One day ago, she experienced...accompanied by nausea and vomiting of gastric contents without bile or coffee-ground material.
history.standard_patient: Yes, as I mentioned earlier, I've been experiencing nausea and have vomited gastric contents without any bile or coffee-ground material since the pain started yesterday.
history.patient: Yeah, like I said before, since that ache came on yesterday, I've been feelin' real queasy and have thrown up what I ate, no yellow stuff or gritty bits like coffee grounds in it.

history.doctor: Thank you for confirming that. Lastly, have you noticed any changes in your urine color or frequency since the surgery?
history.standard_patient: No, my urine color and frequency have remained normal.
history.patient: Well, my pee's been lookin' the usual color and comin' just as often as it always does.

history.doctor: Thank you for answering my questions. Based on the information you have provided, it is possible that you may be experiencing a complication from your recent surgery. The persistent pain in your right side, the shooting pain up to your right shoulder and back, the nausea and vomiting, and the fever are all symptoms that could indicate a problem with your bile duct or gallbladder. I will need to review the results of your recent tests to confirm this diagnosis. In the meantime, I recommend that you rest and stay hydrated. If your symptoms worsen or do not improve, please come back to see me as soon as possible.

history.patient: I took a tumble from a good ol' tree, must've been around 10 feet up, and landed flat on my back on the ground.

history.memory: [Relevant Information]: The patient is experiencing generalized abdominal pain after the fall.
history.standard_patient: The pain in my chest is more of a dull ache, but the abdominal pain is generalized and feels sharper. It started right after the fall.
history.patient: After that tumble, my chest's been hurtin' like a persistent nag, but my belly pain's spread out and hits sharper, if you know what I mean.

history.doctor: I understand. Have you experienced any shortness of breath or difficulty breathing since the fall?
history.standard_patient: No, I haven't had any trouble with breathing.
history.patient: Nah, ain't had no issues with breathin'.

history.memory: [Relevant Information]: History of hypertension for 5 years, appendectomy over 20 years ago.

history.patient: I've been dealing with high blood pressure for about 5 years now, and they took out my appendix more than 20 years back.

If your pain worsens or you experience any difficulty breathing, please seek medical attention immediately.

Physical Condition:None

history.doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
history.standard_patient: I've been experiencing abdominal pain for one month.
history.patient: I've been havin' this belly ache for a whole month now, doc.

history.doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about the pain?
history.standard_patient: The pain comes suddenly and feels like a sharp cutting sensation. It doesn't go to my back and happens now and then. My bowel movements have become less frequent, and I'm also experiencing less flatulence than before. On top of that, I have acid reflux, burping, and feel nauseous, although I haven't vomited.
history.patient: So, doc, I've been havin' this real sudden, sharp pain that feels like someone's slicin' me open from the inside. It ain't reachin' my back, just comes and goes now and then. My trips to the outhouse have gotten fewer, and I'm passin' less gas too. On top of that, there's this burning in my chest, I'm belchin' more, and feelin' queasy all the time, though I ain't thrown up, thankfully.

history.doctor: Thank you for sharing that information with me. Based on what you've described, it sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of a gastrointestinal issue. Have you noticed any changes in your diet or any recent travel that could be contributing to your symptoms?
history.standard_patient: No, there haven't been any significant changes in my diet or recent travels. Everything has been quite normal on that front.
history.patient: Nah, ain't made no big changes in what I eat or gone nowhere special lately. Everything's been just usual on that front.

history.doctor: Alright, thank you for letting me know. Have you had any previous medical conditions or surgeries that could be related to your current symptoms?

history.patient: Yeah, it's been three years since they cut out that ol' belly cancer of mine and had me go through them fancy poison treatments.

history.doctor: I see. Thank you for sharing that information with me. Based on what you've described and your past medical history, it is possible that your current symptoms could be related to your previous cancer treatment. I would like to order some tests to further investigate your symptoms. Have you had any blood tests or imaging studies done recently?
history.standard_patient: No, I haven't had any recent blood tests or imaging studies done.
history.patient: Nah, I ain't had none of them fancy blood checks or picture takin' scans lately.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the chest and abdomen following a vehicle accident 2 hours ago
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports pain in the chest and abdomen that started 2 hours ago following a vehicle accident. The chest pain is localized to the left side, worsens with deep breathing and coughing, accompanied by mild respiratory difficulty, but no hemoptysis. The abdominal pain is a continuous dull ache, localized to the upper left quadrant, without episodic worsening.
Text.Past Medical History: None
Text.Examinations:

Dilatation of the ascending aorta, aortic wall calcification; 4. Bilateral hilar lymph node calcification; 5. Small amount of effusion in the right thoracic cavity, localized thickening of the right pleura; 6. Fractures of the left 3rd to 12th ribs.

文本:
Patient Information:Female, 88 years old, farmer
Chief Complaint:Vomiting blood and experiencing black stools for over 3 hours
Present Illness:The patient suddenly vomited a large amount of dark red blood-like fluid three times three hours ago without any apparent cause, followed by passing tar-like stools three times, the exact amount is unknown, accompanied by palpitations, chest tightness, dizziness, and weakness.
Physical Condition:None
Past Medical History:General health condition is moderate with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and stroke. Long-term use of aspirin for secondary prevention, with residual weakness in the left limbs.

history.doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
history.standard_patient: I'm vomiting blood and have had black stools for over 3 hours.
history.patient: I've been throwin' up blood and my stools turned black as night, been like this for more'n three hours now.

history.doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
history.standard_patient: I suddenly started vomiting a large amount of dark red blood-like fluid three times, about three hours ago. It just happened out of the blue. After that, I've passed stools that looked like tar, three times as well. I couldn't really measure how much it was. Along with this, I'm feeling palpitations, my chest feels tight, I'm dizzy, and I'm incredibly weak.
history.patient: Well, doc, 'bout three hours back, I started chuckin' up a whole lotta dark red stuff, looked like blood to me, happened three times straight outta nowhere. And then, I done had the runs, three times too, but what came out was black as tar. Couldn't tell you how much there was exactly. On top of that, my heart's been racin', my chest feels all squeezed up, I'm seein' stars, and I'm weaker than a newborn calf.

No chills, fever, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, hoarseness, chest tightness, palpitations, night sweats, hemoptysis, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, aversion to oils, poor appetite, jaundice, or urinary symptoms like frequency, urgency, or pain. Symptoms worsened half a month ago, and intermittent self-medication with 'penicillin' did not relieve the symptoms.
Text.Past Medical History: Generally in moderate health, underwent surgery for cervical spondylosis over a year ago with metal implantation. history.standard_patient: My rheumatoid arthritis typically affects my joints, causing pain and stiffness, especially in the morning. Lately, it's been under control with my regular medication, fenbid, though there are occasional flare-ups. The pain I'm experiencing now is different; it's centered in my upper abdomen and feels more like a digestive issue. As for gout, it usually manifests as sudden, severe pain in my big toe, but I haven't had a gout attack recently. So, I don't believe my current symptoms are directly related to my rheumatoid arthritis or gout.
history.patient: So, doc, my joint pains and stiffness, mostly in the mornin', have been pretty manageable with that medicine I take, fenbid. But they still act up now and then. This new ache though, it's sittin' right up in my belly, feels more like a tummy trouble than my usual joint business. And my gout, that's when my big toe acts up something fierce, ain't been botherin' me lately. So, I reckon what's botherin' me now ain't tied to my usual joint or gout troubles.

history.doctor: I see. Thank you for sharing that information with me. Based on your symptoms and history, it is possible that you may be experiencing a case of food poisoning or a stomach infection. I will need to review the results of your recent medical examinations to confirm this diagnosis. In the meantime, I recommend that you stay hydrated and avoid solid foods until we can determine the cause of your symptoms. history.patient: Doc, I'm feeling real bad with this belly ache and queasiness. Could it be from some bad food or a tummy bug? Or maybe those gallstone things or something wrong with the pancreas, 'cause that's where it hurts mostly. And with my years and health background, should we think about other things that might be causing it?

history.doctor: I understand your concerns. Based on your symptoms and history, it is possible that you may be experiencing a case of food poisoning or a stomach infection. I will need to review the results of your recent medical examinations to confirm this diagnosis. In the meantime, I recommend that you stay hydrated and avoid solid foods until we can determine the cause of your symptoms. Is there anything else you would like to share with me about your current condition?
history.standard_patient: Doctor, I appreciate your suggestions, but I feel like we're not exploring other possible causes thoroughly enough. Given my persistent symptoms and the severity of the pain, could we consider doing further tests to check for issues with my gallbladder or pancreas, such as an ultrasound or blood tests? It's important to me that we investigate all avenues to ensure proper treatment.
history.patient: Doc, I'm grateful for your ideas, but I can't shake the feeling we're missing something here. With this nagging pain that won't let up, could we maybe look deeper? Like, check if my gut or that pancreas thingamajig are acting up with some pictures or a simple blood draw? I just want to make sure we've turned every stone before deciding on the fix.

Text.Chief Complaint: Presenting to our hospital due to 'fever and headache for 7 days'.
Text.Present Illness: The patient started experiencing fever 7 days ago, with temperatures reaching up to 37.5°C, and headaches affecting the entire head, occurring intermittently and lasting about 30 minutes each. The headaches, sometimes unbearable, did not respond well to oral pain medication occasionally and did not show a clear correlation with body position. Headaches occurred even when her temperature was normal.
Text.Past Medical History: 45 days ago, the patient had a fever peaking at 39°C with chills, tested positive for the novel coronavirus, followed by a decrease in temperature. 15 days ago, she again developed a fever reaching 38°C, with no cough or expectoration, testing positive for coronavirus antigen. Intermittently took ibuprofen. Denies any history of diabetes, kidney diseases, surgeries, trauma, blood transfusions, and has been vaccinated against COVID-19.
Text.Examinations:
Cranial CT: <\image00032.jpg>.  

 First lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 300 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 420×10^6/L, red blood cells 140×10^6/L, white blood cells 280×10^6/L, 80% polymorphonuclear cells, 20% mononuclear cells.  

 CSF biochemistry: Protein 0.64 g/L, glucose 2.0 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 8.4 mmol/L), lactate 2.4 mmol/L. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus.  

 Second lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 150 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 190×10^6/L, red blood cells 90×10^6/L, white blood cells 100×10^6/L, 64% polymorphonuclear cells, 36% mononuclear cells. Biochemistry: Protein 0.34 g/L, glucose 2.4 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 5.2 mmol/L), lactate 1.8 mmol/L. Adenosine deaminase in CSF 2.4 U/L, in blood 24 U/L. No bacteria seen on Gram stain, no acid-fast bacilli on acid-fast stain. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus. CSF culture showed no bacterial growth. Tuberculosis infection T-cell test negative.  

 CSF cytology: Abnormal, predominantly lymphocytic.
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 5 months, rifampin 0.6g twice daily for 5 months, and ceftriaxone 2g twice daily intravenously for infection control and symptomatic treatment.

 CSF biochemistry: Protein 0.64 g/L, glucose 2.0 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 8.4 mmol/L), lactate 2.4 mmol/L. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus.  

 Second lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 150 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 190×10^6/L, red blood cells 90×10^6/L, white blood cells 100×10^6/L, 64% polymorphonuclear cells, 36% mononuclear cells. Biochemistry: Protein 0.34 g/L, glucose 2.4 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 5.2 mmol/L), lactate 1.8 mmol/L. Adenosine deaminase in CSF 2.4 U/L, in blood 24 U/L. No bacteria seen on Gram stain, no acid-fast bacilli on acid-fast stain. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus. CSF culture showed no bacterial growth. Tuberculosis infection T-cell test negative.  

 CSF cytology: Abnormal, predominantly lymphocytic.
治疗: Treatment includes doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 5 months, rifampin 0.6g twice daily for 5 months, and ceftriaxone 2g twice daily intravenously for infection control and symptomatic treatment.
